column1: Mrs Franklin earned the family bread by taking in lodgers. She was far more active than her husband
column2: who had a very small clerkship in the city; without her aid the children
column5: but by dint of toiling from morning to night
column7: of turning and returning worn-out clothes
column8: and scrubbing and cooking and brushing and cleaning
column9: Mrs Franklin contrived to make two ends meet. Her lodgers said that the rooms they occupied were clean and neat
column10: that their food was well cooked
column11: and above all things that the house was quiet. Therefore they stayed on; year after year the same people lived in the parlours
column12: and occupied the genteel drawing-room floor; and hard as her lot was
column13: Mrs Franklin considered herself a lucky woman
column14: and her neighbours often envied her.
